application.ref: A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

text.p: UCSC Genome Browserhttp://genome.ucsc.eduEnsembl84http://www.ensembl.orgRepeatMasker3.3http://www.re-peatmasker.orgRNAfoldhttp://rna.tbi.univie.ac.at/cgi-bin/RNAfold.cgiMatureBayeshttp://mirna.imbb.forth.gr/Mature-Bayes.htmlMatureBayesmin, 35 cycles of 94℃ for 30 s, 55℃ for 30 s, and 72℃ for 30 s, and a final

elongation at 72℃ for 7 min. Next, quantitative RT-PCR of genes was performed at 94℃ for 15 min, 55 cycles of 94℃ for 10 s, 55℃ for 15 s, and 72℃ for 15 s using the primers shown in Supplementary Table 1. Melting curves were de- termined by increasing the temperature from 55℃ to 99℃ over a period of 30 s. Each sample was amplified in triplicate to confirm reproducibility. U6 was used as a positive control in RT-PCR analysis and as a standard control for normaliza- tion in qRT-PCR. The relative quantitative levels of MER- derived miRNAs were normalized to U6 small-RNA expres- sion levels. The expression values were determined by the 2
method, where ΔC t = C t(miRNA) -C t(U6) .
This work was supported by a grant from the ministry of Education, Republic of Korea (NRF-2015R1D1A1A01056650).
